page.title: 06LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: Thurnscoe dates way back into{Roman times when it was originally called {Ternusc.}We have evidence that Thurnscoe was a Roman village because there is a{Roman Road}running from Southfield Lane all the way to Clayton. The first actual written record of Thurnscoe was in the{Domesday Book - {1087.}Thurnscoe and Deighton were two seperate villages. But today there is only Deighton Street. Thurnscoe was an agricultural village and in{1851}there was approximately {200}people in Thurnscoe. In{1890 HIckleton Main Colliery}was opened and in the next year{1,000 people came to Thurnscoe. With more people Thurnscoe became dirty and many diseases spread, such as typhus and diphtheria. In 1930 houses were built especially for the Hickleton Colliery.
